column1: And because interest rates are quite low by historical standards, the costs of servicing today’s higher levels of debt remain low relative to business income (figure 2).
Despite c rosscurrents, the economy is showing continued growth, strong job creation, and rising wages, all in a context of muted inflation pressures.
Not only is the volume of debt high, but recent growth has also been concentrated in the riskier forms of debt.
Over time , the balance between the two has swung back and forth because of investor demand, the interest rate environment, and other factors.

As with the mortgage boom, the business debt story begins with rapid growth of debt to new highs and a surge in lending to risky borrowers made possible by aggressive underwriting using securitization vehicles.
But the growth in the ratio of busines s debt to GDP in the past decade is much less than the growth in household debt to GDP that we saw in the runup to the Global Financial Crisis .
Now, even after rapid growth, it is still below 75 percent of GDP.

And CLOs, which have facilitated the growth of leveraged loans, have stable funding:  Investors  - 9 - commit funds for lengthy periods, so they cannot, through withdrawals, force CLOs to sell assets at distressed prices.
Bus iness debt growth has moderated somewhat since early 2018, but this might be just a pause.
The growth in business debt does not rel y on short -term funding, and overall funding risk in the financial system is moderate.
